Award.AwardTitle: Modernization and Enhancement of the Seawater System and Research Infrastructure at Northeastern University's Marine Science Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This project renovates 1,310 sq ft. of research laboratory space in Northeastern University's Marine Science Center which houses the Ocean Engineering Lab, the Molecular/Analytical Chemistry Lab, the Shared Molecular Resources Lab, and the Wet Prep Lab. It also provides major infrastructure upgrades to the existing flow-through seawater system which lacks adequate capacity and reliability for present and future research needs. These improvements will help to transform these facilities into an interdisciplinary research hub focused on technological solutions to better address major environmental issues facing the world's coastal marine habitats. The renovations will provide increased research capacity as well as improved facilities for graduate student training. Research that will be enabled include studies of coastal ocean eutrophication, the development of automatic underwater mariculture controllers that can be used in fisheries development projects, marine genomic studies, and investigations of the molecular, physiological, and behavioral responses of marine organisms to stress. Broader impacts of project include increasing infrastructure for science in terms of helping the US stay economically competitive in the area of mariculture and fisheries ecosystem management. Additional impacts include potential applications to national security through the development of remotely controlled vehicles and sensors. The renovation will also enhance the research and educational capabilities of the institution and facilitate broader participation by outside researchers and will serve as a hands-on science outreach engine by serving over 4,000 K-12 school children each year through the Northeastern University Coastal Ocean Science Academy which has many students that are members of under-represented minorities in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This primary goal of this project was to renovate existing research infrastructure at Northeastern University's Marine Science Center in Nahant, Massachusetts. The specific renovations included: 1) a new seawater delivery system that increases delivery rate from ~125 gallons per minute to >500 gallons per minute and increases seawater storage capacity from ~6,000 gallons to 40,000 gallons. This new seawater system supports the research of all resident PIs ad their postdoctoral and graduate students as well as visiting researchers and public and K-12 outreach efforts at the Marine Science Center; 2) the creation of two new research laboratories that focus on research in ecological and evolutionary genomics; 3) the creation of a shared molecular resources laboratory that supports the research of these two primary laboratories as well as other researchers at the Marine Science Center; and 4) a shared wet laboratory that supports ecologically-based research by Marine Science Center PIs and graduate students in the PhD Program in Ecology, Evolution and Marine Biology and the MS Program in Marine Biology, which is part of the Three Seas Marine Biology Program.

We successfully complete all of the goals listed above.

1. The seawater system went on line in April 2014.

2. The two new research laboratories were completed in late spring of 2013 and have served as the research laboratories for resident faculty that use genomic approaches to study the factors affecting WBD disease in Caribbean Reef corals and physiological adaptation in Antarctic fishes.

3. The shared molecular resources laboratory has been on line since the spring of 2013 and has served all Marine Science Center researchers requiring its resources (e.g., -80 freezers, autoclave, PCR machines etc.).

4. The shared wet laboratory has also been on line since spring of 2013 and has served the needs of PIs and students conducting experiments in marine ecology.

Intellectual Merits: In addition to completing the specific infrastructural goals of this project (new seawater system, two new research laboratories, a shared molecular resources laboratory, and a shared wet laboratory), this award ignited a programmatic and infrastructural transformation of the Marine Science Center. During the tenure of this award, we have hired 7 new faculty having broad expertise that dramatically enhances the strategic research areas of our new Urban Coastal Sustainability Initiative. This initiative focuses on creating knowledge about and solutions for the major environmental threats facing coastal marine ecosystems including climate change and sea level rise, pollution, invasive species, biodiversity loss, and over-exploitation of coastal fisheries.

Broader Impacts: These new faculty hires and infrastructural improvements have also led to substantial programmatic changes. Soon after receipt of this award, we created a new academic unit, the Department of Marine and Environmental Science, by merging Marine Science Center faculty with those in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences. This new Department underwent a full review and revision of its undergraduate curriculum so that we could better serve our undergraduate majors in Marine Biology, Environmental Science and Environmental Studies. A major portion of our curriculum also provides courses necessary undergraduate majors in Biology. In addition, we also created new PhD program in Ecology, Evolution and Marine Biology. This graduate program has approximately 30 graduate students, most of which transferred from the graduate program in Biology. Our first admissions season occurred in January 2013, with eight new students joining the program in fall 2013.
